merica.name: Merica (700-1066)
merica.background: This kingdom was the domiant or second most domiant among the Anglo-Saxons from  roughly 600 to 900 AD, reaching it's peak under the reign of King Offa (reigned 757 to 796). His death saw the decline of the kingdom, as through intermarriage and conquest it became a powerful part of Wessex. The kingdom stopped being distinct, even as a vassal, around 900 AD.

wessex.name: Wessex (700-1066)
wessex.background: From the 800s to late 1000s, with the arrival of the Normons, this was the dominant kingdom. Wessex had such power, that after 900, kingdoms like Kent and Sussex were simply 'Greater Wessex'.

late_kent.name: Kent (793-1066)
late_kent.background: Late Kent was a weaker, less accomplished, but proud kingdom.

anglian_kingdoms_heptarchy.name: Anglian Kingdoms Heptarchy (600-700 AD)
anglian_kingdoms_heptarchy.background: The Angles/Anglos had their own kingdoms that were considered part of the 'Heptarchy', specifically East Anglia, Merica, Bernicia, and Deira. Eventually they would be united and/or conquered by the 'Saxon' kingdom of Wessex.

low_bordweall.name: Ceorl Bordweall
low_bordweall.description: A band of freemen/ceorls (Pronouced Churls), who in exchange for their lands and their freedom, serve their lord in martial service 2 months a year. As is the tradition of these people, they fight shoulder to shoulder, in the 'shield wall'. A Ceorl, being free, was not property and neither was his children. The Ceorl often owned his own lands, but pay taxes in return for protection.

great_bordweall.name: Thegn Bordweall
great_bordweall.description: Minor noblemen (Thegn), 'wealthy peasants' (Geneats), and what appears to be some of the middle class, made up a class of 'retainers' who served the king and his nobles. They were the more experienced, martial foundation of Anglo-Saxon Armies. The poorest thegn had enough land to support five whole families.

merican_thegn.name: Merican Thegn Bordweall
merican_thegn.description: Minor noblemen (Thegn), 'wealthy peasants' (Geneats), and what appears to be some of the middle class, made up a class of 'retainers' who served the king and his nobles. They were the more experienced, martial foundation of Anglo-Saxon Armies. The poorest thegn had enough land to support five whole families.

geburs.name: Geburs
geburs.description: Like many cultures, including the Romans, those who couldn't fully afford their own spear and shield often fought as skirmishers. Geburs were indeed 'freemen' and thus 'Ceorls', but they didn't independently own enough land to support their families. As such they had to work 2 days out of the week, at least, on their lord's lands. Many of them were former slaves, or the desendents of such people.

huscarl.name: Huscarls
huscarl.description: A 'housecarl' (Old Norse h√∫skarl, Old English huscarl, translates to 'house man'), was a type of 'retainer' and loyal fighting man, much like many of the minor nobility. What made the Huscarl special, was how it was a mixture of the cultural tradition of the Saxon gedribt 'hearthguard' and the Norse 'hindmen'.

Duguth_Bordweall.name: Duguth Spearmen Bordweall
Duguth_Bordweall.description: The Dugutb (pronounced Doo-gutb) were the more experienced and accomplished warriors, and like many other cultures, including other 'barbarians' and even the Romans, older men typically had better equipment, resilience, and experience. As Saxon warlords or nobles gained power and grew older, they would draw in more and more of these experienced fighters, along with having their inexperienced fighters become experienced over time.

Duguth_Light.name: Light Duguth Warriors
Duguth_Light.description: The Dugutb (pronounced Doo-gutb) were the more experienced and accomplished warriors, and like many other cultures, including other 'barbarians' and even the Romans, older men typically had better equipment, resilience, and experience. As Saxon warlords or nobles gained power and grew older, they would draw in more and more of these experienced fighters, along with having their inexperienced fighters become experienced over time.

light_geoguth.name: Light Geoguth Warriors
light_geoguth.description: A band of Geoguth (Pronouced Yoo-Guths), was the young men and boys of a warband. Typically these men followed less experienced leaders, warlords, and chieftains

heavy_geoguth.name: Geoguth Spearmen Warriors
heavy_geoguth.description: A band of Geoguth (Pronouced Yoo-Guths), was the young men and boys of a warband. Typically these men followed less experienced leaders, warlords, and chieftains

ceorl.name: Ceorl Militia
ceorl.description: A band of freemen/ceorls (Pronouced Churls), typically made up of the conquered peoples living within the lands of a Saxon/Angles king, warlord, or noble. A Ceorl, being free, was not property and neither was his children. The Ceorl often owned his own lands, but pay taxes in return for protection.

earl.name: Eorl
earl.description: Below the rank of 'king', there was the rank of 'eorl' (Later Earl, which was a had a common shared ancestor  with the word 'Jarl), which signified a powerful leader with much land and power (Such as a duke). Such powerful noble leaders often lead armies in the place of the King himself.

ealdorman.name: Ealdorman
ealdorman.description: Below the Eorls were the Ealdormen, who were the appointed rulers of 'shires' and/or members of previously defeated royal families. As such, not every Ealdorman was equal, with the previous leaders of kingdoms having remained part of their power, just with a new King ruling over them. This position was political and not a social rank.

aetheling.name: Aetheling
aetheling.description: The word 'Aetheling' was desended from Saxon, Germanic, and Anglos words, and meant 'belonging to, a royal family'. This term was often used for princes and people of the royal family, who were not the king or queen.

cyning.name: Cyning
cyning.description: The term 'Cyning', is a sibling word of 'king' and as such has the same meaning. As such, the 'Cyning' ruled over a 'Cyningdom', of which there was many before any specific Cyningdom was able to conquer the others.

brythonic_skirmishers.name: Brythonic Skirmishers
brythonic_skirmishers.description: 'Brythonic' refers to people who spoke a 'celtic language', mainly the 'Britons' who lived in Brittany, the Welish, and the Britons who once ruled the lands that would become England. Like many cultures, including the Romans, those who couldn't fully afford their own spear and shield often fought as skirmishers.

modest_bordweall.name: Geneat Bordweall
modest_bordweall.description: Minor noblemen (Thegn), 'wealthy peasants' (Geneats), and what appears to be some of the middle class, made up a class of 'retainers' who served the king and his nobles. They were the more experienced, martial foundation of Anglo-Saxon Armies. A ceorl (freeman) who ended up with enough land to become 'peasant aristocracy' or 'middle class', was a Geneat (They're still a ceorl, and not nobility). Geneats were odd, in that sometimes they were freemen saving up to have enough land to be Thegns (Who are actual minor nobility), and other times they were even richer, but uninterested in being professional soldiers.

strategies.name: Shield Wall
strategies.description: All units with shields and spears equipped (light infantry not included), if that unit moved one or no times this round, and if charged or targeted by a shooting attack it gets +1 Save. This effect remains in place till the unit moves.
strategies.flavor: The bordweall (Old English for 'Shield Wall'), was a tactic and model of fighting that grew popular with the Anglo-Saxons right before or around the start of the Viking Invasion. Communities were organized into sizes that would produce a 'fyrd', which is a part time militia of freemen/ceorls, who fought shoulder to shoulder in formation.

strategies.name: Veterans
strategies.description: All units of thegn may, once for the entire battle, choose to reroll all their dice to hit by shooting or melee. All dice must be rerolled, good or bad.
strategies.flavor: Many years of campaigning have given Wessex or the Anglian kingdoms a pool of hardened veterans.

strategies.name: Combined Units
strategies.description: Any unit with 'Thegn' in the title can be 'merged' with any unit that has 'Ceorl' in its name.
strategies.flavor: Many years of campaigning have given Wessex or the Anglian kingdoms a pool of hardened veterans.
